hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input array. The array is sorted and contains unique integers. This means you won't have to worry about duplicates or unsorted values.
Consider how you can identify the start and end of a range. A range starts at a number and continues until there is a gap in the sequence. Think about how you can track the beginning of a new range.
As you iterate through the array, keep track of the current range's start. When you find a number that does not continue the current range, you will need to finalize that range.

Remember to handle the case where the range consists of a single number. In such cases, the format should just be that number, not a range. Think about how you can differentiate between these two cases.
You can use a loop to go through the array. For each number, check if it is consecutive to the previous number. If it is not, you will need to close the current range and start a new one.
When you finalize a range, think about how you will format it. You should check if the start and end of the range are the same or different to determine the correct string format.
Don't forget to handle the last range after you finish iterating through the array. You will need to check if there is an open range that hasn't been added to your result.
Consider edge cases such as an empty array. What should your function return if the input is an empty list? Make sure to handle this gracefully.
Also, think about the constraints of the problem. The input length can be between 0 and 20, so your solution can be straightforward without performance concerns.

Finally, as you prepare to return your result, ensure that your output matches the required format. You should return a list of strings representing the ranges, so format them correctly before returning.

questionNotes: Input array is sorted and contains unique integers.
Each range should be formatted as 'a->b' if a != b, or 'a' if a == b.
Consider edge cases like an empty input array.
Output should be a list of strings representing the ranges.
